condition.description:
Multiple sclerosis (MS) is a nervous system disease that affects your brain and spinal cord. It damages the myelin sheath, the material that surrounds and protects your nerve cells. This damage slows down or blocks messages between your brain and your body, leading to the symptoms of MS. They can include

  • Visual disturbances
  • Muscle weakness
  • Trouble with coordination and balance
  • Sensations such as numbness, prickling, or "pins and needles"
  • Thinking and memory problems

No one knows what causes MS. It may be an autoimmune disease, which happens when your immune system attacks healthy cells in your body by mistake. Multiple sclerosis affects women more than men. It often begins between the ages of 20 and 40. Usually, the disease is mild, but some people lose the ability to write, speak, or walk.

There is no single test for MS. Doctors use a medical history, physical exam, neurological exam, MRI, and other tests to diagnose it. There is no cure for MS, but medicines may slow it down and help control symptoms. Physical and occupational therapy may also help.

NIH: National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Stroke

carousel_items: Take one capsule daily with or without food.
It's very important you read the Aubagio Medication Guide.
Most common side effects are diarrhea, nausea, hair thinning, and elevated liver blood levels.
Not the best choice if you have liver problems or are on medications that affect the liver.

Liver blood tests need to be done for 6 months once you start taking Aubagio. If these tests are abnormal and liver damage is suspected your doctor will stop the medicine and tell you to start taking cholestyramine for 11 days to lower the toxic level.
You'll need to have a TB test before you start taking Aubagio.
Can cause numbness and tingling of your hands and feet. Let your doctor know if this becomes a problem.

Aubagio increases your risk of infections so tell your doctor if you notice a fever, cough that doesn't go away, or flu-like symptoms. Get your blood counts checked 6 months before starting treatment.
Aubagio can also cause serious and life-threatening liver, lung, skin, kidney and blood pressure effects.
Aubagio will harm your unborn baby and is pregnancy category X. You must have a negative pregnancy test before starting Aubagio.

Both men and women are affected. If they want to have a baby both need to stop taking Aubagio and begin rapid removal process using cholestyramine or activated charcoal for 11 days. Without this process, Aubagio will stay in the body for up to 2 years.

basics.benefits_moa: Aubagio is an immune modulator. Researchers don't know exactly how it works for MS, but it seems to lower your white blood cells and keep them from attacking the nerves in your brain and spinal cord.
basics.bottom_line: Aubagio is an oral medicine that effectively reduces the number of flare-ups, slows physical changes, and decreases the number of new brain lesions in relapsing MS. Because it stays in the body for so long, if you have a serious reaction or possible pregnancy you'll need to have it quickly removed with another medicine.
downsides: Some people have nausea and diarrhea when they start treatment. In most cases, these effects are mild and get better over time.
Aubagio can cause your hair to thin. This is temporary, and your hair will go back to normal after a few months.

You should have certain lab tests to make sure you don't have any problems from taking Aubagio. These include: complete blood count and liver enzyme testing within 6 months before you start treatment, tuberculosis (TB) screening, and blood pressure.
Numbness or tingling in your hands and feet (peripheral neuropathy), different from MS was reported more often than with sugar pill (placebo)
Aubagio may stay in your blood up to 2 years after you stop taking it. You can quickly remove Aubagio the accelerated elimination procedure, but symptoms of your disease may return.
You can't take it if you're pregnant.

You can't take it if you're pregnant.

upsides: You can take it by mouth.
It comes a 7 mg and 14mg dose and only needs to be taken once a day, with or without food.
In clinical studies, Aubagio reduced relapses, slowed disability, and decreased the number of new brain lesions compared to sugar pill (placebo).
Although it may not work for everyone, most people felt it wasn't much of a hassle.

risks_warnings.title: Liver problems
risks_warnings.description: Aubagio may cause serious liver problems, which can be life-threatening. Your risk is higher if you take other medicines that affect your liver. Tell your doctor right away if you have nausea, vomiting, stomach pain, loss of appetite, tiredness, yellowing of your skin/whites of your eyes, or dark urine. You should have blood tests to check your liver function 6 months before you start taking Aubagio then every month for 6 months after.
risk_factors: Taking medicines that affect your liver or cause liver injury

description_processed.orig: Aubagio may cause serious liver problems, which can be life-threatening. Your risk is higher if you take other medicines that affect your liver. Tell your doctor right away if you have nausea, vomiting, stomach pain, loss of appetite, tiredness, yellowing of your skin/whites of your eyes, or dark urine. You should have blood tests to check your liver function 6 months before you start taking Aubagio then every month for 6 months after.

risks_warnings.title: Risk to fetus
risks_warnings.description: Research studies with real people found Aubagio can cause harmful effects on unborn babies. There's also a risk if men take it. Women and men need to be on effective birth control while taking Aubagio. If there's any chance of pregnancy, it's possible to rapidly lower Aubagio levels by giving a medicine that makes it leave your body faster so the risk to your baby is lower. Women should also enroll in the Aubagio pregnancy registry.

Women should also enroll in the Aubagio pregnancy registry.

risks_warnings.title: Drug interactions
risks_warnings.description: The manufacturer recommends you don't take Aubagio if you're taking a drug called leflunomide. The main drug leflunomide is broken down to in the body is Aubagio.

description_processed.orig: The manufacturer recommends you don't take Aubagio if you're taking a drug called leflunomide. The main drug leflunomide is broken down to in the body is Aubagio.

risks_warnings.title: Serious skin reactions
risks_warnings.description: Rare, severe and possibly fatal reactions (e.g. Stevens-Johnson syndrome, toxic epidermal necrolysis)  can happen with leflunomide, an immunosuppressant for rheumatoid arthritis. Aubagio is the main medicine when leflunomide is broken down in the body so there is a risk with this as well. Tell your doctor or get medical help right away if you notice sores or fluid-filled blisters on your skin or peeling skin that's painful. You may need to stop Aubagio and take a medicine to remove it from your body quickly.

Tell your doctor or get medical help right away if you notice sores or fluid-filled blisters on your skin or peeling skin that's painful. You may need to stop Aubagio and take a medicine to remove it from your body quickly.

risks_warnings.title: Numbness in extremities (hands and feet)
risks_warnings.description: Aubagio can cause numbness and tingling in the hands and feet. Most cases got better but some didn't go away when people continued taking Aubagio. Depending on how much this bothers you, your doctor will decide if you need to stop the medicine.
risk_factors: Taking medicines that are toxic to the nervous system

description_processed.orig: Aubagio can cause numbness and tingling in the hands and feet. Most cases got better but some didn't go away when people continued taking Aubagio. Depending on how much this bothers you, your doctor will decide if you need to stop the medicine.

risks_warnings.title: Serious Infections
risks_warnings.description: Aubagio lowers the number of white blood cells in your body increasing risk of serious infections. Call your doctor right away if you have symptoms that include: fever, tiredness, chills, cough, muscle aches or vomiting.  Infections can be reactivated from an inactive virus in your body like tuberculosis (TB). You may need to take medicine for TB before you can begin taking Aubagio. If you didn't get chicken pox and never had a vaccination you'll need to be vaccinated and wait one month before starting Aubagio. Tell your doctor if you've had any vaccines recently and don't get any live vaccines during treatment.

risks_warnings.title: Kidney problems
risks_warnings.description: People taking Aubagio had temporary acute kidney failure thought to be due to high uric acid buildup in the kidneys (uric acid nephropathy). Kidney function started to decrease from 12 weeks to 2 years after the first dose, then returned to normal with continued dosing. It’s not completely clear is there were other reasons for this effect  and people generally didn't have any symptoms.

Kidney function started to decrease from 12 weeks to 2 years after the first dose, then returned to normal with continued dosing. It’s not completely clear is there were other reasons for this effect  and people generally didn't have any symptoms.

risks_warnings.title: Removing Aubagio from your blood
risks_warnings.description: Because it can take up to 2 years for Aubagio to be completely removed from the blood, if you have serious side effects you'll need to take another medicine that helps remove it quickly. Cholestyramine or activated charcoal (accelerated Aubagio procedure) can be given for 11 days. This will remove 98% of Aubagio from your blood.

risks_warnings.title: High potassium
risks_warnings.description: Aubagio has caused high blood potassium levels in people that also had acute kidney failure. Your doctor will do tests to check your potassium levels especially if you already have kidney problems.

description_processed.orig: Aubagio has caused high blood potassium levels in people that also had acute kidney failure. Your doctor will do tests to check your potassium levels especially if you already have kidney problems.

risks_warnings.title: Respiratory problems
risks_warnings.description: Serious and potentially fatal lung problems can happen with leflunomide, an immunosuppressant for rheumatoid arthritis. Aubagio is the main medicine when leflunomide is broken down in the body so there is a risk with Aubagio as well. It can happen suddenly at any time during treatment. If you develop shortness of breath and cough, with or without a fever, call your doctor and get medical care right away. You may need to quickly remove Aubagio with another medicine.

risks_warnings.description: Aubagio can increase your blood pressure. You should have your blood pressure tested before you start then check it regularly during treatment.

carousel_items: Every-other-day injections to the fatty layer under your skin.
Store the powder for reconstitution at room temperature.
Don't shake the medicine after reconstitution.
Can cause flu-like symptoms (headache, fever, muscle pain) right after injections lasting minutes or hours.
Flu-like reactions usually goes away with repeated treatments, or taking acetaminophen or ibuprofen 45 minutes before the injection to reduce the uncomfortable feeling.
Injection site reactions can be common, including swelling, redness, pain, and rarely death of surrounding skin tissues.

basics.benefits_moa: Betaseron is a man-made interferon that's similar to what your body naturally makes. Researchers don't know exactly how it works for MS, but interferons activate your own immune system to control immune responses that have gone out of control.
basics.bottom_line: Betaseron is an injectable medicine effective for relapsing, remitting MS with fewer side effects and every other day dosing.
downsides: Requires injections.
Injection site reactions are common. Symptoms range from pain, redness, and swelling to severe reactions with skin death around the injection site.
Flu-like symptoms are common after interferon injections, but are less likely with Interferon beta-1b in particular.
Blood testing required before and during use based on your other conditions.
Unclear consequences to fetus during pregnancy.

downsides_processed.orig: Requires injections.
Injection site reactions are common. Symptoms range from pain, redness, and swelling to severe reactions with skin death around the injection site.
Flu-like symptoms are common after interferon injections, but are less likely with Interferon beta-1b in particular.
Blood testing required before and during use based on your other conditions.
Unclear consequences to fetus during pregnancy.

upsides: Interferon beta-1b was the first disease modifying agent for MS approved by the FDA to treat relapsing-remitting multiple sclerosis (RRMS).
In short and long-term follow-up studies, Interferon beta-1b was shown to slow MS progression, reduce the number of flair-ups and increase overall survival.
Convenient every-other-day dosing and refrigeration-free storage (before mixing) is less of a hassle.
Interferon beta-1b has been shown to be more effective than Avonex in reducing new lesions, which lowers relapse and disease progression in people with RRMS.
May be a treatment option for people with secondary progressive multiple sclerosis (SPMS).

risks_warnings.title: Serious allergic reactions
risks_warnings.description: Betaseron has been reported to cause hypersensitivity reactions (severe rash, trouble breathing) and rarely, angioedema (life-threatening condition with swelling with or without hives). If you develop these symptoms after your dose or days later, call your doctor and get medical emergency care right away.You may need to stop taking Betaseron.

risks_warnings.title: Suicidal thoughts or behavior
risks_warnings.description: Betaseron may increase the risk of suicidal thoughts or behavior. Watch for new or worsening depression or any unusual changes in mood or behavior, especially during the first few months of treatment or when the dose changes. Tell your doctor right away if you have any of these symptoms.
risk_factors: History of depression or mental illness

risks_warnings.title: Heart problems
risks_warnings.description: Betaseron is not thought to cause adverse effects on the heart, but people taking it who didn't have heart problems developed heart failure and heart muscle weakness. Your doctor will do tests to check your heart function. Tell your doctor if you have ankle swelling, shortness of breath, rapid heartbeat, tightness in your chest or aren't able to lie flat in bed at night because you can't breathe.
risk_factors: History of or current heart disease

risks_warnings.title: Flu-like symptom complex
risks_warnings.description: People who start Betaseron report flu-like symptoms that include fever, chills, sweating, muscle aches and tiredness. Taking a pain reliever or fever reducer like Tylenol or a non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug like Motrin may help. Be sure to ask your doctor first.

risks_warnings.title: Harm to fetus
risks_warnings.description: Betaseron can harm your unborn baby. There's also a risk you can lose your baby (miscarry). Tell your doctor right away if you become pregnant during treatment. You and your doctor should discuss if you should continue or stop taking Betaseron.

description_processed.orig: Betaseron can harm your unborn baby. There's also a risk you can lose your baby (miscarry). Tell your doctor right away if you become pregnant during treatment. You and your doctor should discuss if you should continue or stop taking Betaseron.

risks_warnings.title: Injection site reaction
risks_warnings.description: Injection site reactions can be severe and include pain, redness, swelling, and tissue death. In some cases they need surgical treatment and may not heal, causing scarring. Reactions happen in the first 4 months up to a year after starting and tend get better over time. don't inject into any area that’s not completely healed. If there are several areas, stop taking Betaseron until you have a chance to heal. It’s important that change your injection sites often, follow instructions carefully and learn how to inject it correctly.

risks_warnings.title: Blood cell problems
risks_warnings.description: Betaseron can lower the number of blood cells that help you fight infection and clot blood. White blood cells, red blood cells and platelets can all be affected. Tell your doctor if you feel tired, bruise easily or have any bleeding. you'll need to have blood tests to make sure they don't get too low.

risks_warnings.title: Albumin in the product
risks_warnings.description: Because both Betaseron and Extavia contain albumin, made from human blood, there’s an extremely low risk of transmitting a fatal brain disorder called Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD) or other viral disease. If you have an allergy to albumin talk to your doctor first.

basics.bottom_line: Avonex is an injectable medicine effective for relapsing, remitting MS and has manageable side effects and weekly dosing.

Watch for new or worsening depression or any unusual changes in mood or behavior, especially during the first few months of treatment or when the dose changes. Tell your doctor right away if you have any of these symptoms.

risks_warnings.title: Serious allergic reaction
risks_warnings.description: Avonex has been reported to cause hypersensitivity reactions (severe rash, trouble breathing) and angioedema (life-threatening condition with swelling with or without hives). Get emergency care right away.

description_processed.orig: Avonex has been reported to cause hypersensitivity reactions (severe rash, trouble breathing) and angioedema (life-threatening condition with swelling with or without hives). Get emergency care right away.

risks_warnings.title: Liver damage
risks_warnings.description: Avonex can cause serious liver injury with the risk increasing during the first 6 months after you start. You'll need to have your liver enzymes tested at 1, 3, and 6 months. If liver enzymes are significantly elevated and you have appetite/weight loss, stomach discomfort, vomiting, and notice dark urine, yellowing of skin/eyes, change in stool color, and skin rash, you should stop taking Avonex until your doctor decides if it's safe to re-start.
risk_factors: Taking drugs that are liver toxic

description_processed.orig: Avonex can cause serious liver injury with the risk increasing during the first 6 months after you start. You'll need to have your liver enzymes tested at 1, 3, and 6 months. If liver enzymes are significantly elevated and you have appetite/weight loss, stomach discomfort, vomiting, and notice dark urine, yellowing of skin/eyes, change in stool color, and skin rash, you should stop taking Avonex until your doctor decides if it's safe to re-start.

risks_warnings.title: Injection site reaction
risks_warnings.description: Injection site reactions can be severe and include pain, redness, swelling, infection, and rarely, tissue death. In some cases, these reactions happened more than 2 years after starting Avonex. They usually get better, but may need antibiotics or in severe cases, surgical treatment. It’s important that you follow instructions carefully and learn how to inject Avonex correctly.

risks_warnings.title: Heart problems
risks_warnings.description: Avonex is not thought to cause adverse effects on the heart, but a small number of people with no history of heart problems developed heart failure and heart muscle weakness.  Your doctor should watch you carefully especially when you start Avonex then as long as you continue to take it.

Your doctor should watch you carefully especially when you start Avonex then as long as you continue to take it.

risks_warnings.title: Immune reactions
risks_warnings.description: Your immune system protects you from diseases and infection. If it attacks and destroys healthy cells or tissues, it’s an autoimmune disorder. Rarely, Avonex can cause autoimmune disorders that decreases blood platelets, affects thyroid function, or cause liver damage (autoimmune hepatitis). Your doctor will order blood tests to check for these changes.

Your doctor will order blood tests to check for these changes.

risks_warnings.title: Albumin in the product
risks_warnings.description: Because Avonex vial contains albumin, made from human blood, there’s an extremely low risk of transmitting a fatal brain disorder called Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD) or other viral disease. People who have allergies to albumin shouldn't use the vial formulation of Avonex. The prefilled syringe doesn't contain albumin and may be a better choice for albumin-sensitive people. Make sure you talk to your doctor first.

risks_warnings.title: Seizures
risks_warnings.description: Your doctor will need to decide if Avonex is right for you if you're someone with current or a history of seizures. People taking Avonex had seizures even if they didn't have a history of the condition. It’s not clear if the seizures were caused by their MS, the Avonex or both together.

risks_warnings.title: Risk to fetus
risks_warnings.description: Avonex hasn’t been studied in pregnant women, so the effects on your unborn baby are unknown. If you take it during pregnancy or breastfeed, it’s possible that some medicine may get into your baby’s blood. Talk to your doctor first and if you get pregnant while taking Avonex, you'll need to enroll in the Avonex pregnancy registry.

risks_warnings.title: Bone marrow suppression
risks_warnings.description: Avonex can affect the bone marrow and lower your red and white blood cells and platelets to very low levels. When your blood cells and platelets levels drop too low, you are at more risk for infections, bleeding and bruising and will have to stop taking Avonex until levels correct.  You'll have to get your blood tested regularly at least every 6 months.

carousel_items: Inject yourself at the same time every day into your subcutaneous fat (the layer between your skin and muscle).
Injection site reactions are common. Symptoms include swelling, redness, and pain.
Rarely, can cause a fast and irregular heartbeat, shortness of breath, or flushing that usually goes away after 10-15 minutes.
You can keep syringes at room temperature for up to a month if you can't store them in the refrigerator.

basics.benefits_moa: Copaxone is an immune modulator that alters the immune process. Researchers don't know exactly how it works. It's thought to "trick" out-of-control immune cells and slow their attacks on nerves.
basics.bottom_line: Copaxone is an injectable medicine that's effective for relapsing, remitting MS. It has fewer side effects than other meds, but the self-injections are needed frequently.
downsides: Requires injections, either day or every other day (but no more than three times a week), depending on the dose you're taking.
Injection site reactions are common with pain, redness, swelling, and lipoatrophy (loss of fat under the skin where the injection is made).
Doesn't stop the progression of MS.

downsides_processed.orig: Requires injections, either day or every other day (but no more than three times a week), depending on the dose you're taking.
Injection site reactions are common with pain, redness, swelling, and lipoatrophy (loss of fat under the skin where the injection is made).
Doesn't stop the progression of MS.

upsides: One of the main treatments for relapsing multiple sclerosis (MS) that has been around for many years.
Helps reduce the frequency of MS relapse episodes.
Fewer side-effects than compared to other injectable MS medicines, like interferons.
Can be helpful in maintaining nerve functions.
Likely safe to use during pregnancy.
Copaxone is a possible treatment for primary-progressive MS (PPMS) even though the clinical evidence is not conclusive (there are currently no approved treatments for PPMS).

drugs.name: Copaxone

carousel_items_processed.orig: Inject yourself at the same time every day into your subcutaneous fat (the layer between your skin and muscle).
Injection site reactions are common. Symptoms include swelling, redness, and pain.
Rarely, can cause a fast and irregular heartbeat, shortness of breath, or flushing that usually goes away after 10-15 minutes.
You can keep syringes at room temperature for up to a month if you can't store them in the refrigerator.

risks_warnings.title: Injection reaction
risks_warnings.description: Copaxone causes a systemic reaction right after injecting the medication. The risk is higher after taking it for several months, but can happen earlier. Symptoms include anxiety, chest pain, flushing (feeling of warmth or redness), chest tightness, rapid heartbeat, and trouble breathing. This reaction happens within minutes of the injection, lasts about 15 minutes, and in most cases, goes away without specific treatment, but some people needed emergency care. If you have these symptoms and they get worse or don't go away, get medical care right away.

risks_warnings.title: Skin damage
risks_warnings.description: It’s important that you follow your doctor’s instructions. Read the patient information guide carefully and use the correct technique to inject Copaxone into your skin (subcutaneously). Copaxone can damage your skin or the fatty tissue under the skin (lipoatrophy). Avoid injecting in the same area more than once a week to reduce your risk and let your doctor know if you notice any skin changes after your injections.

Copaxone can damage your skin or the fatty tissue under the skin (lipoatrophy). Avoid injecting in the same area more than once a week to reduce your risk and let your doctor know if you notice any skin changes after your injections.

risks_warnings.title: Chest pain
risks_warnings.description: Copaxone can cause chest pain as part of the post-injection reaction or on its own. Many people taking Copaxone for at least one month reported having more than one episode of chest pain that lasted a few minutes and then went away by itself. If the pain gets worse and doesn't go away, call your doctor and get emergency care.

risks_warnings.title: Immunosuppression
risks_warnings.description: Copaxone can interfere with immune response and function so your body may not recognize "outside" proteins. This can put you at risk for infection and lower your body’s defenses against developing cancer.

carousel_items: Take one capsule daily with or without food.
It's very important you read the Gilenya Medication Guide. Don't change your dose or stop the medicine without asking your doctor.
You'll need to be watched for at least 6 hours in a doctor's office after taking your first dose because it can cause serious heart rate and blood pressure problems.
Gilenya increases your risk of infections. Get blood tests 6 months before starting treatment.
Use effective birth control or plan to stop Gilenya 2 months before getting pregnant. If you do become pregnant while on Gilenya, you'll need to enroll in the Gilenya pregnancy registry.
Tell your doctor if you've had any vaccines recently. Don't get any live vaccines while taking Gilenya.
Your doctor will monitor your eyes, lungs, and liver for up to 2 months after stopping Gilenya.

basics.benefits_moa: Gilenya is an immune modulator. Researchers don't know exactly how it works, but it seems to stop your white blood cells from attacking the nerves in your brain and spinal cord.
basics.bottom_line: Gilenya is an oral medication that has a lot of side effects, but it reduces the number of flare-ups, slows physical changes, and decreases the number of new brain lesions in relapsing MS.
downsides: Taking more than the 0.5 mg dose won't give more benefits, but will only cause more side effects.
Gilenya can remain in your blood for up to 2 months after you stop taking it. Your immune response won't work as well during this time.

Not the best choice if you've had a heart attack, stroke, or have been in the hospital for heart failure in the past 6 months. The risk of serious heart rate effects is higher when taken with certain drugs (methadone, erythromycin, citalopram, ketoconazole) or if you have low potassium or magnesium.
If you have to re-start Gilenya after stopping it for 2 weeks or more, you'll have to take your first dose at your doctor's office again.
If you didn't get chicken pox and never had a vaccination, you'll need to be vaccinated and wait one month before starting Gilenya.

downsides_processed.orig: Taking more than the 0.5 mg dose won't give more benefits, but will only cause more side effects.
Gilenya can remain in your blood for up to 2 months after you stop taking it. Your immune response won't work as well during this time.

Not the best choice if you've had a heart attack, stroke, or have been in the hospital for heart failure in the past 6 months. The risk of serious heart rate effects is higher when taken with certain drugs (methadone, erythromycin, citalopram, ketoconazole) or if you have low potassium or magnesium.
If you have to re-start Gilenya after stopping it for 2 weeks or more, you'll have to take your first dose at your doctor's office again.
If you didn't get chicken pox and never had a vaccination, you'll need to be vaccinated and wait one month before starting Gilenya.

upsides: Gilenya is the first once-daily pill you can take for relapsing forms of multiple sclerosis (MS).
Studies show it lowers relapse rates better than placebo and Avonex, and it delays the progression of physical disabilites better than placebo.
Gilenya also reduced the number of new MS lesions better than Avonex.

risks_warnings.title: Heart problems
risks_warnings.description: You'll have to take the first does in a medical facility with your doctor or medical staff watching how your body reacts. Gilenya can cause your heart rate to slow down, especially for 6 to 24 hours after your first dose. Your heart rate should return to normal within one month after you start taking Gilenya. Call your doctor or get medical care right away if you have slow heart rate, dizziness, tiredness, or if you feel like your heart is skipping beats.
risk_factors: Taking with drugs that slow heart rate

description_processed.orig: You'll have to take the first does in a medical facility with your doctor or medical staff watching how your body reacts. Gilenya can cause your heart rate to slow down, especially for 6 to 24 hours after your first dose. Your heart rate should return to normal within one month after you start taking Gilenya. Call your doctor or get medical care right away if you have slow heart rate, dizziness, tiredness, or if you feel like your heart is skipping beats.

risks_warnings.title: High blood pressure
risks_warnings.description: High blood pressure caused by Gilenya is reported as an adverse reaction in about 5% of people. It usually happens after one month of taking it and can continue during treatment. You should have your blood pressure checked by your doctor on a regular basis while taking Gilenya.

description_processed.orig: High blood pressure caused by Gilenya is reported as an adverse reaction in about 5% of people. It usually happens after one month of taking it and can continue during treatment. You should have your blood pressure checked by your doctor on a regular basis while taking Gilenya.

risks_warnings.title: Serious infections
risks_warnings.description: Gilenya lowers the number of white blood cells in your body and can increase your risk of serious infections. This can continue for up to 2 months after you stop taking the medicine. Call your doctor if you think you have symptoms of an infection that include: fever, tiredness, chills, cough, muscle aches, or vomiting. Tell your doctor if you've had any vaccines recently and don't get live vaccines while taking Gilenya.

description_processed.orig: Gilenya lowers the number of white blood cells in your body and can increase your risk of serious infections. Call your doctor if you think you have symptoms of an infection that include: fever, tiredness, chills, cough, muscle aches, or vomiting. Tell your doctor if you've had any vaccines recently and don't get live vaccines while taking Gilenya.

risks_warnings.title: Eye problems
risks_warnings.description: You should have an eye exam before you start taking Gilenya, then again in 3-4 months. Cases of macular edema, an eye condition, were reported usually during the first 3-4 months of treatment. Some people had no symptoms but it can cause the same vision problems you get with an MS flare-up. Call your doctor right away if you have blurry or tinted vision, light sensitivity, or a blind spot in the middle of your vision. Symptoms usually got better once people stopped Gilenya, but some people continued to have vision problems.

risks_warnings.title: Risk to fetus
risks_warnings.description: Although Gilenya hasn’t been studied in pregnant women, studies in animals showed there may be a serious risk to babies. If you take it during pregnancy or breastfeed, it’s possible that some medicine may get into your baby’s blood. It takes 2 months to remove Gilenya from your body, so the risk remains after you stop the medicine. If you get pregnant while taking it, you'll need to enroll in the Gilenya pregnancy registry.

risks_warnings.title: Respiratory problems
risks_warnings.description: Gilenya can cause a decrease in lung capacity during the first month of taking it. Some people stopped taking it because of unexplained shortness of breath. It appears to be reversible after stopping the medicine, but it's not completely known. If you're having these symptoms, your doctor can decide to do lung function testing or stop the medication.

risks_warnings.title: Liver problems
risks_warnings.description: Gilenya can cause elevated liver enzymes. You should have blood tests to check your liver before you begin treatment. If you develop symptoms of nausea, vomiting, belly pain, tiredness, loss of appetite, or you notice yellowing of your skin/whites of eyes or dark urine while taking Gilenya, your doctor will decide if you need to stop. Liver enzymes usually return to normal within 2 months after you stop the medicine.

carousel_items: You can crush the tablets and take Hydrocortisone with your food or drink. Do not open up a capsule, since they need to be swallowed whole.
Be sure not to stop taking Hydrocortisone suddenly, as it can lead to loss of appetite, nausea, weakness, low blood pressure, and low blood sugar.
Some people gain weight while taking Hydrocortisone. Using a weight loss program, eating smaller portions, and drinking a glass of water before meals tend to help.

basics.benefits_moa: Hydrocortisone is a short-acting corticosteroid. It lowers inflammation by preventing your capillaries (small blood vessels) from leaking out excess fluid and chemicals that cause swelling.
basics.bottom_line: Hydrocortisone is identical to an essential hormone that humans produce and has been proven to work safely.
downsides: In the first few weeks, your doctor might adjust the dose of Hydrocortisone multiple times.
You may be at an increased risk of infection if you take high doses of Hydrocortisone, or if you take it in combination with other immunosuppressive medications.
Your body could stop making its own cortisol once it gets used to Hydrocortisone. If so, you'll likely have to keep taking Hydrocortisone for a really long time.
Depending on why your doctor prescribed Hydrocortisone to you, corticosteroids can have different effects on your body.

downsides_processed.orig: In the first few weeks, your doctor might adjust the dose of Hydrocortisone multiple times.
You may be at an increased risk of infection if you take high doses of Hydrocortisone, or if you take it in combination with other immunosuppressive medications.
Your body could stop making its own cortisol once it gets used to Hydrocortisone. If so, you'll likely have to keep taking Hydrocortisone for a really long time.
Depending on why your doctor prescribed Hydrocortisone to you, corticosteroids can have different effects on your body.

upsides: Normal doses of hydrocortisone have been safely and successfully used for over 60 years. It's especially good for people using it as a long-term cortisol supplement.
Hydrocortisone converts into cortisol, a natural hormone, which will not interfere with other medications you may be taking.
Taking a dose of Hydrocortisone in the evening doesn't affect your ability to sleep.
At safe doses, Hydrocortisone can actually increase your body's ability to fight infection.

carousel_items_processed.orig: You can crush the tablets and take Hydrocortisone with your food or drink. Do not open up a capsule, since they need to be swallowed whole.

Some people gain weight while taking Hydrocortisone. Using a weight loss program, eating smaller portions, and drinking a glass of water before meals tend to help.

risks_warnings.title: Adrenal suppression (HPA axis suppression)
risks_warnings.description: Adrenal suppression leading to adrenal crisis can occur if you lower your dose or stop taking Hydrocortisone too quickly. Symptoms include joint or muscle pain, extreme low energy and depression. Changes in your Hydrocortisone dose need to be done slowly over time. Talk to your doctor before you make any changes or stop the medication.
risk_factors: Lowering dose or stopping too quickly especially after long-term treatment
Stress such as trauma, surgery or infection

description_processed.orig: Adrenal suppression leading to adrenal crisis can occur if you lower your dose or stop taking Hydrocortisone too quickly. Symptoms include joint or muscle pain, extreme low energy and depression. Changes in your Hydrocortisone dose need to be done slowly over time. Talk to your doctor before you make any changes or stop the medication.

risks_warnings.title: Increased risk for infections
risks_warnings.description: If you take Hydrocortisone for a long time it can increase your risk of all types of infections, make it hard to tell if you have one, take longer to fight and be more serious. Be careful not to be in contact with anyone who has the chicken pox or measles. If you had tuberculosis (TB) in the past your doctor will need to monitor you while taking Hydrocortisone. You may need to take medicine to prevent getting it or treat it if your TB comes back. Talk to your doctor before taking Hydrocortisone if you haven't had vaccinations against certain viral diseases, are under stress or regularly around sick people.
risk_factors: Contact with people who have viral illness
History of bacterial or viral conditions

description_processed.orig: If you take Hydrocortisone for a long time it can increase your risk of all types of infections, make it hard to tell if you have one, take longer to fight and be more serious. Be careful not to be in contact with anyone who has the chicken pox or measles. If you had tuberculosis (TB) in the past your doctor will need to monitor you while taking Hydrocortisone. You may need to take medicine to prevent getting it or treat it if your TB comes back. Talk to your doctor before taking Hydrocortisone if you haven't had vaccinations against certain viral diseases, are under stress or regularly around sick people.

risks_warnings.title: Kaposi's sarcoma
risks_warnings.description: It’s rare, but taking Hydrocortisone for a long period of time, can increase your risk of Kaposi’s sarcoma, a type of cancer that can affect both the skin and internal organs. Your doctor will monitor you closely while you're taking Hydrocortisone and if this develops, will work with you to slowly lower your dose and stop the medication.

Your doctor will monitor you closely while you're taking Hydrocortisone and if this develops, will work with you to slowly lower your dose and stop the medication.

risks_warnings.title: Psychiatric changes
risks_warnings.description: Like most corticosteroid medicines, Hydrocortisone may cause changes in your mood or behavior. Tell your doctor right away if you become depressed, have mood swings, trouble sleeping, irritability or anxiety, hyperactivity,  delusions or hallucinations while taking this medicine. If you need to make any changes or slowly taper your dose, talk to your doctor first.

risks_warnings.description: Hydrocortisone can thin the bones and decrease the growth rate in children. Talk to the doctor about medicine choices that won't negatively affect growth. Use the lowest possible dose to treat the condition and have the doctor monitor your child’s height during treatment.

description_processed.orig: Hydrocortisone can thin the bones and decrease the growth rate in children. Talk to the doctor about medicine choices that won't negatively affect growth. risks_warnings.title: Harm to fetus
risks_warnings.description: Taking Hydrocortisone if you're pregnant or breast-feeding can harm your unborn baby. If you need to take a systemic corticosteroid during pregnancy, the lowest dose that will help treat your condition should be used for the shortest time, especially during your first trimester. Your doctor will let you know if there are other medicine choices that are safer (e.g. inhaled steroids for asthma).

risks_warnings.title: Stomach and intestinal problems
risks_warnings.description: Taking Hydrocortisone increases the risk of injury to the lining of your stomach and intestine including irritation, tears/holes and ulcers. You should avoid alcohol/alcoholic beverages because it can worsen stomach irritation. Tell your doctor or get medical care right away if you have stomach pain, notice blood or dark colored stools when you go to the bathroom.
risk_factors: Active or history of stomach or duodenal ulcers
Taking Hydrocortisone with other medicine that can cause stomach problems

carousel_items: Be sure to take Prednisolone in the morning to help imitate your bodies release of cortisol. This will also help you sleep better at night.
You can crush the tablets and take Prednisolone with your food or drink. Do not open up a capsule, they need to be swallowed whole.
Be sure not to stop taking Prednisolone suddenly, as it can lead to loss of appetite, nausea, weakness, low blood pressure, and low blood sugar.
Stay away from people who are sick because Prednisolone can make lower your bodies ability to fight infection.
Many people gain weight while taking Prednisolone. Using a weight loss program, eating smaller portions, and drinking a glass of water before meals tend to help.
Avoid direct sunlight while taking this medication. When you can’t avoid it, be sure to use sunscreen. It’s also important to put on a long-sleeved shirt, pants, hat, and sunglasses.

basics.benefits_moa: Prednisolone is an intermediate-acting synthetic corticosteroid. Researchers are not sure exactly sure how it decreases inflammation, but it seems to block the proteins that trigger inflammation. It also seems to affect the hormones used in balance our water and break carbohydrates down.
basics.bottom_line: Prednisolone and similar anti-inflammatory medications work great, but you have to be willing to deal with a list of side effects.
downsides: You will probably have to take additional medications in order to treat your condition.

Prednisolone and similar corticosteroids come with lots of side effects including an including an increased appetite, irritability, swelling of the ankles and feet, increased blood sugar, and decreased healing.
Taking Prednisolone as a long-term medication may lead to permanent side effects.
You must have blood tests often while taking Prednisolone to make sure your body is processing it correctly.
You can’t be around others who are sick, conceive a child, or get vaccinations while taking Prednisolone.

risks_warnings.title: Eye Problems
risks_warnings.description: Prednisolone may cause cataracts or glaucoma, increased eye pressure and possibly eye nerve damage. You may also be more at risk for certain eye infections. Don't take if you have herpes simplex of the eye. Let your doctor know if you have blurry vision, eye pain or any vision changes.

risks_warnings.title: Heart and Kidney Problems
risks_warnings.description: Taking large doses of Prednisolone can cause high blood pressure, water retention and an imbalance of your electrolytes. Your doctor may advise you restrict salt intake, and take calcium supplements.

description_processed.orig: Taking large doses of Prednisolone can cause high blood pressure, water retention and an imbalance of your electrolytes. Your doctor may advise you restrict salt intake, and take calcium supplements.

risks_warnings.title: adrenal suppression
risks_warnings.description: Adrenal suppression leading to adrenal crisis can occur if you lower your dose or stop taking Prednisolone too quickly. Symptoms include joint or muscle pain, extreme low energy and depression. Changes in your Prednisolone need to be done slowly and over time. Talk to your doctor before you make any changes or stop your medication.

risks_warnings.title: increased risk for infection
risks_warnings.description: If you take Prednisolone for a long time it can increase your risk of infections, make it hard to tell if you have one, take longer to fight, and be more serious. Be careful not to be in contact with anyone who has the chicken pox or measles. If you had tuberculosis (TB) in the past your doctor will need to monitor you while taking Prednisolone. You may need to take medicine to prevent getting it or treat it if your TB comes back. Talk to your doctor before taking Prednisolone if you haven't had vaccinations against certain viral diseases, are under stress or regularly around sick people.

basics.benefits_moa: Medrol is a corticosteroid that's similar to what your body naturally makes. It reduces swelling and other immune responses that can cause you pain, discomfort, or harm.
basics.bottom_line: Medrol is corticosteroid available in many forms (oral, injectable) that's great for controlling the unwanted symptoms from your immune responses and will make you feel better. There are lots of side effects but most of are tolerable or can be managed.
downsides: Lots of side effects, especially with long term use.
Short-term use can cause mood changes, trouble sleeping and increase in blood pressure, blood sugar, and possible water retention.
Long-term use can cause problems with skin, bone, eye health and put you at a higher risk for infections.
People with certain conditions will have to pay extra attention to their symptoms or may have to adjust the dose of other medicines when taking Medrol.
When using corticosteroids for more than 1 week, you will need to work with a doctor to get off the medicine slowly.

risks_warnings.title: Kaposi's sarcoma

surveys.tip: Develop a sense of humor...the one thing I can say for sure is it is unpredictable...xo

surveys.question: What tip would you give someone like me who was just diagnosed?
surveys.tip: Try not to panic. Learn as much as you can but don't overwhelm yourself- the disease is different for everyone. While there is no cure, at least now there are non-injection options, which is a big advance.

surveys.question: What tip would you give someone like me who was just diagnosed?
surveys.tip: Get informed. There have been so many treatment advances and maybe what you remember from your past, seeing people with MS, doesn't apply anymore.

surveys.question: Besides medications, what else has worked for you?
